sen.j: 興世王（おきよおう/おきよのおほきみ 生年不詳 - 天慶4年（940年））は平安時代中期の皇族。
sen.e: Prince Okiyo (?-940) was a member of the Imperial family in the mid-Heian period.
Prince Okiyo (? - 940) was a member of the Imperial Family in the mid-Heian period.
Prince Okiyo (? - 940) was a member of the Imperial Family in the mid-Heian period.

sen.j: 桓武天皇の第3皇子伊予親王の四世子孫という説があるが、明治時代に作られた系図によるもので信用できない。
sen.e: There is a story that he was a descendant after four generations of Imperial Prince Iyo, the third prince of Emperor Kanmu, but this story is incredible because it is formed on the basis of the genealogy made in the Meiji period.

There is a story that he was a fourth-generation descendant of Imperial Prince Iyo, the third prince of Emperor Kanmu, but this story lacks credibility because it is formed on the basis of a genealogy made during the Meiji period.

There is a theory that he was the fourth-generation descendant of Imperial Prince Iyo, the third prince of Emperor Kanmu, but this theory lacks credibility because it is based on a family tree made during the Meiji period.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 諸国の受領を歴任していたと思われるが、詳細は不明。
sen.e: It seems that he assumed the post of Zuryo (the head of the provincial governors) in various districts successively, but details are uncertain.
It seems that he assumed the post of Zuryo (the head of the provincial governors) in various districts successively, but the details are not clear.
It seems that he assumed the post of Zuryo (the head of the provincial governors) in various districts successively, but the details were not clear.

sen.j: 承平天慶の乱首謀者の一人。
sen.e: He was one of the masterminds of the Johei and Tengyo War.
He was one of the masterminds of the Johei and Tengyo War.
He was one of the masterminds of the Johei and Tengyo War.

sen.j: 従五位下武蔵国権守、将門私授上総介。
sen.e: He was the Surrogate Governor of Musashi Province with the court rank of Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth rank, lower grade) and also the Kazusa no suke (Assistant Governor of Kazusa Province) appointed by TAIRA no Masakado.

He was the Surrogate Governor of Musashi Province with the court rank of Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) and also the Kazusa no suke (Assistant Governor of Kazusa Province) appointed by TAIRA no Masakado.

He was the Musashi-no-kuni Gon-no-kami (Substitute Provisional Governor of Musashi Province) with the court rank of Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) and also the Kazusa no suke (Assistant Governor of Kazusa Province) appointed by TAIRA no Masakado.
sen.cmt: 「武蔵国権守」を他の記事にあわせました。

tit.cmt: 他の記事にあわせました。

sen.j: 承平 (日本)8年（938年）、武蔵国国司（権守(ごんのかみ)＝守の代理）として赴任。
sen.e: He arrived at Musashi Province as the Surrogate Governor.
He arrived in Musashi Province as the Surrogate Governor.
He arrived in Musashi Province as kokushi (provincial governors) (Gon-no-kami, substitute for Kami, the Governor) in 938.
sen.cmt: 「938年」を補足、表現を変えました。

sen.j: 武蔵国司源経基と共に赴任早々に検注を実施した。
sen.e: Immediately after his arrival, he conducted the land survey with MINAMOTO no Tsunemoto, an officer of Musashi Province.
Immediately after his arrival, he conducted a land survey with MINAMOTO no Tsunemoto, an officer of Musashi Province.
Immediately after his arrival, he conducted a land survey with MINAMOTO no Tsunemoto, an officer of Musashi Province.

sen.j: しかし、足立郡郡司武蔵武芝は武蔵では正官の国司赴任以前には検注が行われない慣例になっていたことから、検注を拒否する。
sen.e: However, MUSASHI no Takeshiba, the local magistrate of Adachi County, refused the land survey by the surrogate Governor because Adachi County had decided not to conduct the survey customarily unless the official Governor would arrive at the county.

However, MUSASHI no Takeshiba, the local magistrate of Adachi County, refused the Surrogate Governor's land survey because Adachi County had decided not to conduct the survey in the customary way unless the official Governor arrived in the county.

However, MUSASHI no Takeshiba, the local magistrate of Adachi County, refused the Gon-no-kami's land survey because Adachi County had decided not to conduct the survey in the customary way unless the official Governor arrived in the county.

sen.j: これに対し、興世王と経基は兵を繰り出して武芝の郡家を襲い、略奪を行った。
sen.e: Therefore, Prince Okiyo and Tsunemoto sent troops and gave orders to attack and sack the Takeshiba's office..
Therefore, Prince Okiyo and Tsunemoto sent troops and gave orders to attack and sack the Takeshiba's office.
In response, Prince Okiyo and Tsunemoto sent troops and gave orders to attack and sack Takeshiba's office.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 武芝は山野に逃走、幾度となく文書で私財の返還を求めたが、興世王らは応じないどころか合戦の準備をして威嚇までしてみせた。
sen.e: Takeshiba ran away to fields and mountains requesting the restoration of his property in writing, however, not only Prince Okiyo refused his request, he threatened Takeshiba by showing him the preparation for a battle as well.

Takeshiba ran away to the fields and mountains, requesting the restoration of his property in writing; however, Prince Okiyo not only refused his request but also threatened Takeshiba by showing him the battle preparations that had been made.

Takeshiba ran away to the fields and mountains, requesting the restoration of his property in writing; however, Prince Okiyo not only refused his request but also threatened Takeshiba by showing him the battle preparations that had been made.

sen.j: この話を聞いて私兵を率いて武芝の許を訪れた平将門は興世王と武芝を会見させて和解させた。
sen.e: TAIRA no Masakado, who visited Takeshiba with his troops after learning this dispute, settled the dispute peacefully by arranging a meeting between Prince Okiyo and Takeshiba.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: TAIRA no Masakado, who visited Takeshiba with his troops after learning of the dispute, settled the problem peacefully by arranging a meeting between Prince Okiyo and Takeshiba.
TAIRA no Masakado, who visited Takeshiba with his troops after learning of the dispute, settled the problem peacefully by arranging a meeting between Prince Okiyo and Takeshiba.

sen.j: しかしながら、その酒宴の最中に経基の営所が武芝の兵に囲まれるという事態が起こり、生命の危険を感じた経基は慌てて京へ逃げ帰ってしまう。
sen.e: However Tsunemoto's quarters were besieged by the Takeshiba's troops in the midst of the feast, with the result that Tsunemoto, feeling a threat to his life, returned to Kyoto hastily.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, Tsunemoto's quarters were besieged by the Takeshiba's troops in the midst of the feast, with the result that Tsunemoto, feeling a threat to his life, hastily returned to Kyoto.
However, Tsunemoto's quarters were besieged by the Takeshiba's troops in the midst of the feast, with the result that Tsunemoto, feeling a threat to his life, hastily returned to Kyoto.

sen.j: 経基は興世王と武芝と将門が共謀して謀反を謀っていると訴え、将門の主人の太政大臣藤原忠平が事の実否を調べることにし、御教書を下して使者を東国へ送った。
sen.e: Accepting the complaints appealed by Tsunemoto that Prince Okiyo, Takeshiba and Masakado plotted a rebellion in conspiracy, Daijo-daijin (Grand minister of state) FUJIWARA no Tadahira, Masakado's lord, sent an envoy to Togoku (the eastern part of Japan, particularly Kanto region) after issuing a migyosho (document for informing people of the decision of Third Rank or upper people) for judging whether the complaints were right or wrong.

Accepting the complaints of appeal by Tsunemoto that Prince Okiyo, Takeshiba and Masakado plotted a rebellion in conspiracy, Daijo-daijin (Grand Minister of State) FUJIWARA no Tadahira, Masakado's lord, sent an envoy to Togoku (the eastern part of Japan, particularly the Kanto region) after issuing a migyosho (document informing people of Third Rank or higher regarding a decision) in order to judge whether the complaints were right or wrong.

Accepting the complaints of appeal by Tsunemoto that Prince Okiyo, Takeshiba and Masakado were plotting a rebellion in conspiracy, Daijo daijin (Grand Minister of State) FUJIWARA no Tadahira, Masakado's lord, sent an envoy to Togoku (the eastern part of Japan, particularly the Kanto region) after issuing a migyosho (documents for informing of decisions made by third or upper ranked authorities) to investigate whether the complaints were true.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。Daijo-daijin、ハイフン削除しました。

sen.j: 興世王、将門、武芝は承平9年5月2日付けで常陸・下総・下野・武蔵・上野5カ国の国府の「謀反は事実無根」との証明書をそえて送ると朝廷は疑いを解いた。
sen.e: The certifications sent by Prince Okiyo, Masakado and Takeshiba dated of the 2nd of May, 939 dispelled the court's doubts, because the provincial office of five provinces, Hitachi, Shimofusa, Shimotsuke, Musashi and Kozuke, suggested in the certification that the rumor of plotting rebellion is groundless.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The certifications sent by Prince Okiyo, Masakado and Takeshiba dated May 2, 939, dispelled the court's doubts because the provincial office of five provinces--Hitachi, Shimofusa, Shimotsuke, Musashi and Kozuke--suggested in the certification that the rumor of a planned rebellion was groundless.

The certifications sent by Prince Okiyo, Masakado and Takeshiba dated May 2, 939, dispelled the court's doubts because the provincial office of five provinces--Hitachi, Shimofusa, Shimotsuke, Musashi and Kozuke--suggested in the certification that the rumor of a planned rebellion was groundless.

sen.j: 逆に経基は誣告罪で左衛門府に拘禁された。
sen.e: To the contrary, Tsunemoto was confined to the Saemon-no-fu (Imperial Police office) for libel.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: To the contrary, Tsunemoto was confined to the Saemon-no-fu (office of the Imperial Police) for libel.
To the contrary, Tsunemoto was confined to the Saemon-no-fu (office of the Imperial Police) for libel.

sen.j: しかし、同年5月に正任国司百済王貞連が赴任すると事態が一転する。
sen.e: Things, however, suddenly turned after the arrival of the official Governor Sadafusa (Prince Kudara) in May, 939 at the province.
However, things suddenly turned after the arrival in the province of Governor Sadafusa (Prince Kudara) in May 939.
However, things suddenly turned after the arrival in the province of Governor Sadafusa (Prince Kudara) in May of the same year, 939.

sen.j: 興世王は貞連と不仲で、貞連は興世王を国庁の会議に全く列席させなかった。
sen.e: As Prince Okiyo and Sadafusa were at odds, Sadafusa forcibly excluded Prince Okiyo from the conferences held at the provincial office.
Because Prince Okiyo and Sadafusa were at odds, Sadafusa forcibly excluded Prince Okiyo from the conferences held at the provincial office.
Because Prince Okiyo and Sadafusa were at odds, Sadafusa forcibly excluded Prince Okiyo from the conferences held at the provincial office.

sen.j: やがて興世王は任地を離れて下総の将門のもとに身を寄せる。
sen.e: Prince Okiyo left the province soon to stay with Masakado in Shimofusa Province.
Prince Okiyo soon left the area and stayed with Masakado in Shimofusa Province.
Prince Okiyo soon left the area of appointment and stayed with Masakado in Shimofusa Province.

sen.j: 翌年、常陸国の豪族藤原玄明と常陸介藤原維幾が対立し、玄明に助力した将門は常陸国府を襲撃、国府を占領した。
sen.e: When a confrontation arose between FUJIWARA no Haruaki, a powerful regional clan in Hitachi Province, and FUJIWARA no Korechika, the Hitachi no suke (Assistant Governor of Hitachi Province) next year, Masakado assisting Haruaki attacked the Hitachi provincial office and occupied it.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The following year, when a confrontation arose between FUJIWARA no Haruaki, a powerful regional clan in Hitachi Province, and FUJIWARA no Korechika, the Hitachi no suke (Assistant Governor of Hitachi Province), Masakado, assisting Haruaki, attacked the Hitachi provincial office and occupied it.

The following year, when a confrontation arose between FUJIWARA no Haruaki, a powerful regional clan in Hitachi Province, and FUJIWARA no Korechika, the Hitachi no suke (Assistant Governor of Hitachi Province), Masakado, assisting Haruaki, attacked the Hitachi provincial office and occupied it.

sen.j: 将門は印璽を奪い、維幾を京へ追い返してしまう。
sen.e: After Masakado deprived Korechika of the provincial seal, he sent Korechika back to Kyoto.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: After Masakado deprived Korechika of the provincial seal, he sent Korechika back to Kyoto.
After Masakado deprived Korechika of the provincial seal, he sent Korechika back to Kyoto.

sen.j: 将門の側近となっていた興世王は「案内ヲ検スルニ、一國ヲ討テリト雖モ公ノ責メ輕カラジ。
sen.e: Prince Okiyo, who had been a close adviser of Masakado, said to Masakado, " Considering the current situation, your responsibility is not light even if you insist that you occupied only one province.
Prince Okiyo, who had been Masakado's close adviser, said to him, "Considering the current situation, your responsibility is not light even if you insist that you occupied only one province.
Prince Okiyo, who had been Masakado's close adviser, said to him, 'Considering the current situation, your responsibility is not light even if you insist that you occupied only one province.
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションにしました。

sen.j: 同ジク坂東ヲ虜掠シテ、暫ク氣色ヲ聞カム。
sen.e: Then you should occupy not only one province but also the whole area of Bantou (Togoku)".
Then you should occupy not only one province but also the whole area of Bantou (Togoku)."
Then you should occupy not only one province but also the whole area of Banto (Togoku).'
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションにしました。

sen.j: 」と将門に東国制覇を勧めた。
sen.e: and recommended him to conquer the Togoku.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Thus he recommended that Makakado conquer the Togoku.
Thus he recommended that Makakado conquer the Togoku.

sen.j: 将門はこの言に乗り下野国・上野国の国府を占領して世に言う承平天慶の乱を起こした。
sen.e: Adopting Prince Okiyo's advise, Masakado occupied the provincial offices of Shimonotsuke Province and Kozuke Province, which was called the Johei and Tengyo War.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Adopting Prince Okiyo's advice, Masakado occupied the provincial offices of Shimonotsuke and Kozuke provinces, in what came to be called the Johei and Tengyo War.
Adopting Prince Okiyo's advice, Masakado occupied the provincial offices of Shimonotsuke and Kozuke provinces, in what came to be called the Johei and Tengyo War.

sen.j: 上野国府で新皇を僭称した将門の下、時の主宰者となった興世王は藤原玄茂と共に独自に除目を発令し、自らは上総国介に任命される。
sen.e: Under Masakado who named himself the new emperor at the Kozuke provincial office, Prince Okiyo, who became the most influential person at that time, issued the Jimoku (ceremony for appointing officials) in his own right with FUJIWARA no Harumochi, being appointed to the Assistant Governor of Kazusa Province.

Under Masakado, who named himself the new emperor at the Kozuke provincial office, Prince Okiyo, who became the most influential person at that time, issued the Jimoku (ceremony for appointment of officials) in his own right with FUJIWARA no Harumochi, being appointed as the Assistant Governor of Kazusa Province.

Under Masakado, who named himself the new emperor at the Kozuke provincial office, Prince Okiyo, who became the most influential person at that time, issued the Jimoku (ceremony for appointment of officials) in his own right with FUJIWARA no Harumochi, being appointed as the Assistant Governor of Kazusa Province.

sen.j: この将門らの謀反により翌天慶3年（940年）に以前の訴えが事実になって経基は放免された。
sen.e: With the rebellion by Masakado and others, Tsunemoto was acquitted in 940 because his past appeal had come true.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: With the rebellion by Masakado and others, Tsunemoto was acquitted in 940 because his past appeal had at last been approved.
With the rebellion by Masakado etc., Tsunemoto was acquitted the following year, in 940, because his past appeal became a fact.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 将門追討が開始される。
sen.e: The court ordered to send a punitive force against Masakado.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The court ordered that a force be sent to punish Masakado.
The court ordered that a force be sent to punish Masakado.

sen.j: 同年2月14日に平貞盛・藤原秀郷らとの合戦で将門が討ち死にすると、将門の勢力は一気に瓦解した。
sen.e: With the death of Masakado in the battle with TAIRA no Sadamori and FUJIWARA no Hidesato on February 14th, 940, the influence of Masakado decreased immediately.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Masakado died in the battle against TAIRA no Sadamori and FUJIWARA no Hidesato on February 14, 940, whereupon his influence immediately ceased.
Masakado died in the battle against TAIRA no Sadamori and FUJIWARA no Hidesato on February 14 of the same year, 940, whereupon his influence immediately ceased.

sen.j: 首謀者は次々と討たれ、興世王も2月19日上総で藤原公雅に討たれた。
sen.e: Masterminds of the rebellion, including Prince Okiyo, who was killed by FUJIWARA no Kinmasa in Kazusa Province on February 19th, were killed one after another.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The masterminds of the rebellion, including Prince Okiyo, who was killed by FUJIWARA no Kinmasa in Kazusa Province on February 19, were killed one after another.
The masterminds of the rebellion were killed one after the other, including Prince Okiyo, who was killed by FUJIWARA no Kinmasa in Kazusa Province on February 19.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。
